titleStmt.title: Hugh Davies to Thomas Pennant, 10 August 1795

list.item: he refers to Roth: Flor. Germ. 1. p. 314. and to no other author.
Festuca ovinaFor the 'Cistus hirsutus', 'Anthoxanthum odoratum', 'Cynosurus cristatus', and 'Festuca ovina', see the text of the main letter and accompanying notes.
Plantago lanceolata'Plantago lanceolata', ribbed grass. OED s.v. ribbed grass.
Lotus corniculatusSee T. Martyn, translating J.-J Rousseau (1785), where 'The wild species [=Lotus corniculatus]' is named 'common Bird's-foot Trefoil'. OED s.v. bird's-foot, bird-foot.
Trifolium repens'Trifolium repens', white clover. OED s.v. honeysuckle.
Polygala vulgaris 'Polygala vulgaris', rogation flower or the common milkwort, which was 'formerly made into garlands and carried in processions on Rogation Days'. OED s.v. rogation.
Poterium sanguisorba'Poterium Sanguisorba', the common burnet or salad burnet, from its use in salads. OED s.v. salad, salad burnet.
Agrostis caninaSee OED s.v. bent, bent-grass, which quotes Lightfoot, Flora Scotica (1778) I, p. 93, 'Agrostis canina, Brown Bent-grass'.
_________ stolonifera'Agrostis stolonifera', marsh bent-grass or creeping bent-grass, a variant of 'stolonifera' but much taller and not matting to form a turf. OED s.v. marsh, n.1, marsh bent.
Avena flavescens'Avena flavescens', golden oat, or yellow oat-grass. OED s.v. yellow, yellow oat grass.
Festuca duriusculaFor images of specimens of the 'Festuca duriuscula', several collected in Switzerland, see here, items 7–16 [accessed 12 August 2019].
Trifolium flexuosum – Gmel Syst. Nat.For the reference to 'Trifolium flexuosum', see Alberti Gvilielmi Rothii, Tentamen florae Germanicae. Tomvs I. (Lipsiae, I. G. Mülleriano, 1788), p. 314. p. 1142.

div.p: As far as I can judge, all you can say of the above grasses is that Mr. Dickinson pointed those species out as chiefly constituting the herbage of your lofty commons, although I suspect it an imperfect list, and that there must be several other species of Grass, and, I doubt not some species of Juneus'Junius' is a species of rush. See Atlas of Hawai'i (3rd edn., Honolulu: University of Hawai'i Press, 1998), p. 113. and Carex'Carex', a large genus of grassy-looking plants. OED s.v. carex. besides other plants.

I truly rejoice at the account you gave of yourself; I by no means intended you should yourself have taken any trouble about Ellis Richardson; and I wish he knew I should be sorry he should sell his Cow solely on my account; I had rather suffer a little myself than distress a fellow-creature, particularly at such a time as this –
I dined with Mr. Panton about ten days ago, he was in good spirits, and looked much better than, from report, I expected to have seen him.

I request you will not think me peevish, for I really am not; you will gain Mr. DickinsonA list headed 'Plants collected by S. Dickinson July 21st. 1795' mentions several of the plants named in this letter from Hugh Davies to Pennant, including in a category deemed 'Rare', the 'Cistus hirsutus', underneath which Pennant has noted in pencil a location of its growth known to him, 'Pen y Gelli'. CR2017/TP213/5. no credit in saying that he pointed out to you as rare plants Anthoxanthum odoratum,'Anthoxanthum odoratum', spring grass. OED s.v. spring grass. Cynosurus cristatus'Cynosurus cristatus', dog's-tail grass. OED s.v. dog grass. & Festuca ovina;'Festuca ovina', listed as a 'social' plant on account of its growth in clumps, patches or masses with other members of its species. It has been identified with 'coquioule' and possibly 'haver-grasse' [haver grass]. OED s.v. social; cockle, n.1. they and the remainder of your list of Augt. 2d, together with those contained in your P.S. of Augt. 7th. are exceedingly common, and all of rather inferior rank in respect of utility: I shall indeed except Cistus hirsutusFor the 'Cistus hirsutus' see see here [accessed 12 August 2019]. Hugh Davies pointed out an example to Pennant on Din Sylwy in Anglesey. See A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), II, p. 254. and Trifol: flexuosumFor an essay on the 'Trifolium alpestre', which names the 'Trifol. flexuosum' as a discovery of Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin, see Adam Afzelius, 'The Botanical History of Trifolium alpestre, medium, and pratense', Transactions of the Linnean Society, I (1790), 202–248, esp. 210. as a plant I do not know. (See the other page)
Loth to put you to the expence of a double letter by transcrible both your lists; I shall however return your own memorandum, when I have an opportunity to inclose.
I beg my respects to Mrs. Pennant and am

closer.salute:
Dear Sir
your most obliged &
Obedt. Servt.

postscript.p:
P.S.
A Catalogue of the Birds & Plants of Priestholm Isle is on your return. –
